metadata.cleaningNote: Filtered PDF artifacts using automated script, manually curated additional principles

shelter: Shelter protects from wind, rain, and temperature extremes.
Build shelter before dark to avoid working in dangerous conditions.
Insulation from the ground is as important as overhead cover.
Natural shelters like caves or fallen trees can save time and energy.
Location is crucial - avoid valleys where cold air settles and areas prone to flooding.
A small shelter is easier to heat than a large one.
Always test the stability of natural shelters before relying on them.
Reflective surfaces behind you can double the warmth from a fire.
Ventilation prevents carbon monoxide poisoning in enclosed shelters.
water: Water is critical - dehydration kills faster than starvation.
Always purify water from natural sources to avoid illness.
In cold climates, melting snow requires energy and lowers body temperature.
Ration sweat, not water - work during cooler hours to conserve water.
Clear running water from high elevations is generally safer than still water.
Boiling water for one minute kills most pathogens.
Morning dew can be collected from vegetation using absorbent cloth.
Never drink seawater - it accelerates dehydration.
Signs of dehydration include dark urine, dizziness, and decreased urination.
fire: Fire provides warmth, water purification, signaling, and psychological comfort.
Prepare tinder, kindling, and fuel before attempting to light a fire.
Protect fire from wind and rain once started.
Fire requires constant attention and fuel gathering.
Dead standing wood is drier than wood on the ground.
Build fire on bare ground or rock to prevent spread.
Three fires in a triangle is an international distress signal.
Feather sticks increase surface area for easier ignition.
Never leave a fire unattended in dry or windy conditions.
food: Food is the lowest priority in short-term survival.
Energy spent hunting or foraging must be worth the calories gained.
Some plants and animals are poisonous - know what you're eating.
Insects and grubs are often safe protein sources if properly prepared.
Cook all wild meat thoroughly to kill parasites and bacteria.
Avoid plants with milky sap, bitter taste, or three-leafed patterns.
Fish and insects are easier to catch than large game.
Universal edibility test can help identify safe plants when necessary.
Berries eaten by birds are not always safe for humans.
navigation: Stay put if you're lost and people know your location.
Navigate only if you know your destination and have energy.
The sun rises in the east and sets in the west.
Following water downstream often leads to civilization but uses energy.
Mark your trail to avoid walking in circles.
North Star remains fixed while other stars rotate around it.
Moss on trees is not a reliable indicator of north.
High ground provides better vantage points for orientation.
Travel during daylight hours to avoid injury and conserve energy.
signaling: Three of anything is the international distress signal.
Signal when aircraft or potential rescuers are nearby.
Bright colors, smoke, mirrors, and noise all attract attention.
Ground-to-air signals should be large and contrasting.
Signal mirrors can be seen for miles on sunny days.
Smoke signals work best on calm, clear days.
Conserve signaling devices until you have a confirmed sighting.
SOS in Morse code is three short, three long, three short.
Maintain signals constantly once rescue attempt begins.
firstAid: Stop bleeding first - it can be life-threatening within minutes.
Treat injuries promptly before they worsen.
Hypothermia and hyperthermia are serious threats requiring immediate action.
Immobilize fractures to prevent further damage.
Clean wounds thoroughly to prevent infection.
Elevate bleeding limbs above the heart when possible.
Direct pressure is the most effective way to control bleeding.
Symptoms of shock include pale skin, rapid pulse, and confusion.
Remove constrictive clothing and jewelry before swelling increases.
priorities: Rule of 3s: You can survive 3 minutes without air, 3 hours without shelter in harsh conditions, 3 days without water, and 3 weeks without food.
STOP principle: Stop, Think, Observe, Plan before taking action.
Stay put if lost: Movement without a plan can make rescue harder and waste energy.
Shelter is often more critical than food or water in extreme weather.
Signal for rescue using three of anything (fires, whistle blows, mirror flashes) - the international distress signal.
Address immediate dangers first, then focus on long-term survival.
Conserve energy by working smarter, not harder.
Plan for the worst and hope for the best.
Take inventory of resources before making decisions.
psychology: Panic leads to poor decisions and wastes energy.
Maintaining morale is essential for survival.
Small victories and routines help maintain mental stability.
Fear is natural but must be controlled through planning and action.
A positive mental attitude significantly increases survival chances.
Set realistic short-term goals to maintain motivation.
Keep your mind active to prevent despair and hopelessness.
Remember loved ones to strengthen your will to survive.
Accept the reality of your situation before you can improve it.
weather: Wind chill makes temperatures feel colder and increases heat loss.
Wet clothing loses insulating properties and accelerates hypothermia.
Shade and reducing activity helps in extreme heat.
Weather changes can turn a manageable situation deadly.
Layer clothing to trap warm air and allow temperature regulation.
Cotton kills in cold, wet conditions - choose wool or synthetics.
Protect extremities first - fingers, toes, ears, and nose.
Sweat management prevents heat loss through evaporation.
Recognize early signs of hypothermia and hyperthermia.
